Se levantó de la silla, con la intención de ir a buscar ayuda, pero sus piernas parecían pesar toneladas y no podía moverse. La habitación comenzó a girar a su alrededor, y se sintió como si estuviera flotando en el aire. Su mente estaba en blanco, incapaz de procesar lo que había sucedido. El libro, el libro que su hermano le había dejado antes de irse, seguía en su mano, como si fuera un peso que lo atara a la realidad. No podía dejar de pensar en lo que su hermano le había dicho antes de irse: "No te rindas, hermano, no te rindas". Pero ¿cómo podía seguir adelante sin él? La vida parecía haberse detenido, y él no sabía cómo seguir respirando sin su hermano a su lado.

en_second_half: dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, Montag shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.

en_results_raw: ground, their knuckles white as they strained to hold on to the only thing that seemed real in a world that had lost all sense of gravity. The air was heavy with an eerie silence, the only sound the soft rustling of leaves and the distant hum of a dying engine. The men's labored breathing was the only reminder that they were still alive, still clinging to the earth as if it was a lifeline to a world that was rapidly slipping away from them. The sky above was a deep, foreboding grey, like a physical manifestation of the darkness that had taken hold of their hearts. As they struggled to find their footing, the earth beneath them seemed to be shifting, as if it too was trying to break free from the weight of their desperation. The men's eyes were fixed on some point in the distance, their faces etched with a mix of fear and determination, their bodies trembling with the effort of holding on to the only thing that seemed to matter in a world that had lost all sense of purpose.

es_results_raw: la tierra húmeda y fría, sus ojos cerrados como si el miedo y la desesperación los hubieran congelado en un estado de estupor. El viento aullaba a su alrededor, un lamento que parecía resonar en sus almas, pero ellos permanecían inmóviles, como si la muerte misma los hubiera petrificado en ese instante. La nieve comenzó a caer sobre ellos, cubriéndolos con una capa de blanco que les daba un aspecto de muñecos abandonados, pero en sus rostros, la expresión de terror y desesperación seguía siendo visible, como si la vida misma se hubiera escapado de sus cuerpos y se hubiera refugiado en algún lugar más seguro, dejándolos atrás como sombras de lo que un día fueron. La nieve siguió cayendo, cubriendo la escena con una capa de silencio, pero en el corazón de cada uno de ellos, el miedo y la desesperación seguían latiendo, como un eco de lo que había sido y lo que nunca sería de nuevo.

He thought of the books he had burned, the knowledge he had destroyed, the ideas he had silenced. The faces of his friends, of his wife, of the people he had betrayed, flashed before him like a parade of ghosts, their eyes accusing, their voices whispering in his mind. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he turned back to the wall, his eyes scanning the lists of forbidden books, the names leaping out at him like beacons of hope and defiance. The kerosene-soaked pages seemed to whisper to him, their words burning brighter with every passing moment, and he knew that he could not escape the truth forever. The fire within him was growing, a flame that threatened to consume him, to burn away the lies and the deceit, to reveal the truth that he had been hiding from for so long. He took a step back, his heart pounding in his chest, as the words of the poet echoed louder in his mind, a reminder of the price he had paid for his silence, and the price he might yet pay for his freedom.

es_results: La llama crepitaba con un sonido áspero, como si estuviera devorando no solo los libros, sino también la memoria de la humanidad. Montag sintió un escalofrío al pensar en todas las historias, las ideas y las verdades que se estaban quemando. Los nombres
es_results_raw: La llama crepitaba con un sonido áspero, como si estuviera devorando no solo los libros, sino también la memoria de la humanidad. Montag sintió un escalofrío al pensar en todas las historias, las ideas y las verdades que se estaban quemando. Los nombres de los libros se reducían a cenizas, pero él sabía que la verdadera destrucción no era la de los libros, sino la de la imaginación y la creatividad que representaban. La sociedad había decidido que la libertad de pensamiento era un peligro, y por eso había creado un sistema de control que eliminaba cualquier idea que pudiera ser considerada subversiva. Montag se preguntó si él mismo había sido parte de ese sistema, si había contribuido a la destrucción de la literatura y la cultura. La llama seguía ardiendo, devorando todo en su camino, y Montag se sintió atraído hacia ella, como si estuviera siendo arrastrado hacia un abismo sin fondo.

He dodged and weaved through the narrow corridors, his hatchet at the ready, as the sirens wailed and the police cars screeched to a halt outside. The blackness seemed to swallow him whole, but he knew these corridors like the back of his hand, every twist and turn, every hidden alcove and secret passage. He had lived in this building for years, and he knew its secrets better than anyone. The books, the ones that had once brought him so much joy, now seemed like a distant memory, a relic of a life he had left behind. He thought of his wife, Mildred, and her love of the phonograph records, the way she would play them over and over, the music swirling around her like a vortex. He thought of the fire, the one that had changed everything, the one that had set him on this path. And he thought of the Captain, the man who had taken him under his wing, who had taught him the ways of the world. But most of all, he thought of the books, and the words that had once brought him so much happiness. He wondered if he would ever find them again, if he would ever be able to read them again. The thought sent a pang through his heart, and he quickened his pace, his hatchet at the ready, as he made his way deeper into the heart of the building.

en_results_raw: Her presence was a disruption to the carefully constructed facade, a crack in the veneer of camaraderie and shared secrets. The men, usually so adept at hiding their true intentions, were now stumbling over their words, their laughter and jokes sounding forced and awkward. The woman's silence was a palpable thing, a heavy weight that pressed down on the group, making it hard to breathe. She was a wild card, a variable that no one had accounted for, and her presence was throwing off the delicate balance of the ritual. The men exchanged nervous glances, their eyes darting towards her with a mix of fear and resentment, as if they were unsure of how to react to this unexpected twist. The air was thick with tension, and the room seemed to be holding its breath, waiting for someone to make the first move, to break the silence and restore the status quo. The smell of disinfectant and stale air filled his nostrils as he slowly sat up, his eyes still closed, trying to grasp the reality of the situation. The faint sound of a machine beeping in the background seemed to be the only thing that broke the silence, a stark contrast to the emptiness that filled his chest. He slowly swung his legs over the side of the bed, his feet dangling in the cold air, and took a deep breath, trying to process the fragmented images that lingered in his mind. The memories of her, of their life together, of the laughter and the tears, all seemed to be shrouded in a thick fog, making it difficult for him to distinguish what was real and what was just a product of his imagination. He stood up, his legs wobbly, and took a few tentative steps, his eyes still closed, as if trying to hold onto the memories, to keep them from slipping away, to keep her with him just a little bit longer.

Beatty's thoughts turned to the journey that had brought him to this moment, the twists and turns that had led him to this small, cramped space, and the people he'd met along the way. vi_results_raw: The nhà hát hiện đại này không chỉ mang đến cho khán giả những trải nghiệm mới mẻ mà còn là một biểu tượng kiến trúc nổi bật của thành phố. Các nhà thiết kế đã sử dụng những vật liệu cao cấp và công nghệ hiện đại để tạo nên một không gian rộng rãi và thoải mái cho khán giả. Bên trong các phòng vách kính, ánh sáng tự nhiên từ các cửa sổ lớn được tận dụng tối đa để tạo nên một bầu không khí tươi mát và trong lành. Các màu sắc đẹp mắt được sử dụng để trang trí cho các phòng, tạo nên một tổng thể hài hòa và thu hút. Ngoài ra, các nhà hát còn được trang bị các công nghệ hiện đại để đảm bảo chất lượng âm thanh và hình ảnh tốt nhất cho khán giả. Điều này giúp cho khán giả có thể tận hưởng được những trải nghiệm giải trí tuyệt vời trong một không gian hiện đại và sang trọng.

El libro, el libro que su hermano le había dejado antes de irse, seguía en su mano, como si fuera un peso que lo atara a la realidad. No podía dejar de pensar en lo que su hermano le había dicho antes de irse: "No te rindas, hermano, no te rindas". Pero ¿cómo podía seguir adelante sin él? en_results_raw: But my grandfather used to tell me stories about his brother, who was a soldier in a far-off land, and how he never came back home. It was a war that lasted for years, and many lives were lost. My grandfather would always say that it was a senseless conflict, one that left deep scars on the families of those who fought in it. He would often speak of the pain and the grief that lingered long after the war had ended, and how it affected the people who were left behind. I remember feeling a mix of sadness and curiosity whenever he spoke about it, wondering what it must have been like to live through such a difficult time. As I grew older, I began to realize that the impact of war extends far beyond the battlefield, affecting not just the soldiers who fought, but also their families, their communities, and their countries as a whole. It's a complex and multifaceted issue, one that requires careful consideration and understanding. My grandfather's stories had sparked a sense of empathy within me, and I knew that I wanted to learn more about the history of war and its effects on people's lives.

En mi experiencia, la cesárea es un procedimiento médico que debe ser utilizado con moderación y solo en casos en los que sea absolutamente necesario. Pero, en la mayoría de los casos, el parto vaginal es la opción más segura y natural. Además, la sociedad debe fomentar la educación y la conciencia sobre la importancia de la salud reproductiva y la planificación familiar. Esto puede ayudar a reducir la tasa de cesáreas innecesarias y promover una mayor conciencia sobre los riesgos y beneficios de cada método de parto. I've been trying to finish a novel for years now, but it's proving to be a tougher task than I anticipated. The characters just won't cooperate, and the plot keeps changing direction on me. I've rewritten the entire thing at least five times, but I'm still not satisfied with the result. Maybe I'm just not cut out for this writing thing, or maybe I'm just not good enough. en_results: The shadows cast by the flickering streetlights danced across the walls, like restless spirits, as the wind rustled through the broken panes, and the faint scent of smoke wafted through the air, mingling
en_results_raw: The shadows cast by the flickering streetlights danced across the walls, like restless spirits, as the wind rustled through the broken panes, and the faint scent of smoke wafted through the air, mingling with the smell of last night's whiskey and stale cigarettes. The neighbour's voices, hushed and urgent, seemed to be discussing something in hushed tones, their words barely audible over the creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath their feet. Montag's eyes lingered on the torn covers, a testament to the chaos that had erupted within these walls, and he felt a shiver run down his spine as he wondered what had transpired here, and what the night might still hold.

The books, however, were scattered all over the alley, their pages fluttering gently in the breeze, as if trying to escape the chaos that had just unfolded. Montag's thoughts were a jumbled mess, a cacophony of sounds and images that refused to make sense, like a radio dial spinning wildly, picking up every station at once. He tried to move, to crawl, to get up, but his body seemed to be stuck, weighed down by an invisible force, as if the world itself was holding him back. The books, however, seemed to be calling to him, their words whispering secrets in his ear, tempting him to rise, to get up, to keep moving, to keep reading, to keep living.

en_first_half: Montag pulled back into the shadows. Directly ahead lay a gas station, a great chunk of porcelain snow shining there, and two silver beetles pulling in to fill up. Now he must be clean and presentable if he wished,
en_second_half: to walk, not run, stroll calmly across that wide boulevard. It would give him an extra margin of safety if he washed up and combed his hair before he went on his way to get where . . . ?
en_results: to make a good impression on the woman he had been thinking about all day. He had been assigned to escort her to a high-society party tonight, and he knew that his appearance would be the
en_results_raw: to make a good impression on the woman he had been thinking about all day. He had been assigned to escort her to a high-society party tonight, and he knew that his appearance would be the first thing she would notice. He quickly checked his watch, realizing he had only a few minutes to spare before he had to leave. He took a deep breath, smoothed out his uniform, and began to walk towards the gas station, his eyes fixed on the two silver beetles, which were now being refueled by a gruff-looking attendant. As he approached, he noticed that one of the beetles was a sleek, black model with tinted windows, while the other was a more modest, silver one with a faded paint job. The attendant, a burly man with a thick beard, looked up and caught Montag's eye, and for a moment, they simply stared at each other, sizing each other up. Montag broke the silence by nodding curtly and continuing on his way, his eyes fixed on the woman's house, which was just a short walk from the gas station. He could see the lights were already on, and he knew she would be expecting him soon. He quickened his pace, his heart beating slightly faster with anticipation. As he walked, he couldn't help but think about the woman, wondering what she would be like, and what the evening had in store for him. He had heard rumors that she was a high-society woman, with connections to the very top echelons of power, and he knew that this was an opportunity he couldn't afford to miss. He took a final glance at the gas station, and then turned towards the woman's house, his eyes fixed on the door, waiting for her to let him in.

The sound of the engine grew louder still, and Montag knew it was time to act.

El vehículo se acercaba cada segundo más, y los agentes se preparaban para detenerlo, pero no sabían qué tipo de vehículo era ni qué velocidad podría alcanzar. El vehículo se acercaba a una velocidad de unos trescientos kilómetros por hora, lo que era casi imposible para cualquier vehículo normal. Los agentes se miraban entre sí con una mezcla de miedo y curiosidad, preguntándose qué podría estar pasando. De repente, el vehículo se detuvo en seco, justo en la puerta de la estación, y los agentes se acercaron con cautela, armados y listos para cualquier situación. Pero cuando abrieron la puerta, no encontraron a nadie dentro. El vehículo estaba vacío, pero el ruido que había hecho era como si hubiera estado lleno de personas. Los agentes se miraron entre sí, confundidos y asustados, preguntándose qué había pasado. ¿Qué tipo de vehículo era ese? ¿Cómo había logrado esa velocidad? Y, sobre todo, ¿qué había pasado con los ocupantes? Los agentes se quedaron allí, sin saber qué hacer, mientras el vehículo permanecía en silencio, como si esperando a que alguien se acercara para responder a sus preguntas.

en_results_raw: <output>His feet pounded the pavement in a frantic rhythm, echoing off the grey walls of the buildings as he careened through the deserted streets. The sound of his ragged breathing and the scuttling of the beetle behind him were the only noises that broke the oppressive silence. He stumbled and staggered, his eyes fixed on some point ahead, his mind consumed by a maddening chaos of thoughts and emotions. The world around him seemed to be spinning, colors blurring together in a kaleidoscope of madness. He was a man possessed, driven by some unseen force that propelled him forward with an unstoppable momentum. The concrete beneath his feet seemed to stretch out endlessly, a seemingly endless expanse of grey that threatened to swallow him whole. And yet he kept running, driven by a desperate need to escape, to flee from the demons that haunted him. The beetle, sensing its master's distress, scurried after him, a tiny, insignificant creature in a world gone mad. As he ran, the city seemed to grow smaller, the buildings shrinking to dollhouse proportions as he hurtled through the streets, a tiny, insignificant speck in the vast expanse of the universe. His legs ached, his lungs burned, but still he ran, driven by a primal urge to escape, to flee from the darkness that threatened to consume him whole. The world around him was a blur, a chaotic mess of colors and sounds, but he kept running, his feet pounding out a frantic rhythm on the concrete, his heart pounding in his chest like a drum. And then, just as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. He stopped, his chest heaving, his legs trembling beneath him. The beetle, sensing its master's exhaustion, scurried up to him, its tiny antennae twitching as it regarded him with a curious expression. For a moment, the two of them stood there, frozen in a tableau of exhaustion and despair. And then, slowly, the man began to speak, his voice barely above a whisper as he struggled to make sense of the chaos that had consumed him. "What am I doing?" he whispered, his eyes scanning the empty streets as if searching for some answer. The beetle, sensing its master's confusion, scurried up his arm, its tiny claws clicking against his skin as it settled onto his shoulder. And in that moment, something strange and wonderful happened. The man felt a sense of peace wash over him, a sense of calm that seemed to seep into his very bones. The world around him began to slow down, the colors and sounds fading into a soft, golden light that seemed to envelop him whole. And in that moment, he knew that he was not alone. The beetle, sensing its master's peace, seemed to nod in agreement, its antennae twitching in a tiny, almost imperceptible gesture. Together, the two of them stood there, bathed in the warm, golden light, a sense of understanding and connection that seemed to transcend the boundaries of species and sanity. And in that moment, the man knew that he was not alone, that there was something greater than himself out there, something that connected him to the world and to all its creatures. The beetle, sensing its master's newfound peace, scurried up to his ear, its tiny voice whispering a single, simple word: "Run." And in that moment, the man knew that he would always be running, running from the darkness, running towards the light, running towards a future that was full of hope and possibility. The beetle, sensing its master's resolve, scurried up to his shoulder, its tiny claws clicking against his skin as it settled into its new position. And together, the two of them stood there, a man and his beetle, a tiny, insignificant speck in the vast expanse of the universe, but a speck that was full of hope and possibility. The beetle, sensing its master's excitement, scurried up to his ear, its tiny voice whispering a single, simple word: "Forward." Se preguntó qué había sido de su familia, si habían sobrevivido al ataque. ¿Habían sido evacuados a tiempo? ¿O habían sido evacuados a un refugio seguro? Montag se estremeció al pensar en la posibilidad de que algo hubiera pasado con ellos. Se acercó a la casa de su vecino, el viejo Granger, para buscar noticias. Al llegar, encontró a Granger sentado en su porche, con una mirada sombría en su rostro. "¿Qué pasó?", preguntó Montag, sin poder ocultar su preocupación. Granger se levantó y se acercó a él, con una expresión seria en su rostro. "Fue un ataque nuclear", dijo, sin necesidad de explicaciones. Montag se sintió como si le hubieran golpeado con un mazo. Nunca había imaginado que algo así fuera posible. El mundo que conocía había cambiado para siempre.

He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

Y cuando murió, de pronto me di cuenta de que no lloraba por él, sino por las cosas que hacía. Lloraba porque nunca más volvería hacerlas, nunca más volvería a labrar otro pedazo de madera y no nos
es_second_half: ayudaría a criar pichones en el patio ni tocaría el violín como él sabía hacerlo, ni nos contaría chistes. Nunca me he sobrepuesto a su muerte. A menudo, pienso en las tallas maravillosas que nunca han cobrado forma a causa de su muerte. Cuántos chistes faltan al mundo, y cuántos pichones no sido tocados por sus manos. Configuró el mundo, hizo cosas en su beneficio. en_second_half: dirt, and they were all shouting to keep their eardrums from bursting, to keep their sanity from bursting, mouths open, Montag shouting with them, a protest against the wind that ripped their faces and tore at their lips, making their noses bleed.

en_results_raw: ground, their knuckles white as they strained to hold on to the only thing that seemed real in a world that had lost all sense of gravity. The air was heavy with an eerie silence, the only sound the soft rustling of leaves and the distant hum of a dying engine. The men's labored breathing was the only reminder that they were still alive, still clinging to the earth as if it was a lifeline to a world that was rapidly slipping away from them. The sky above was a deep, foreboding grey, like a physical manifestation of the darkness that had taken hold of their hearts. As they struggled to find their footing, the earth beneath them seemed to be shifting, as if it too was trying to break free from the weight of their desperation. The men's eyes were fixed on some point in the distance, their faces etched with a mix of fear and determination, their bodies trembling with the effort of holding on to the only thing that seemed to matter in a world that had lost all sense of purpose.

es_second_half: el polvo y todos gritaban para evitar la rotura de sus tímpanos, para evitar el estallido de su razón, con las bocas abiertas, y Montag gritaba con ellos, una protesta contra el viento que les arrugaba los rostros, les desgarraba los labios y les hacía sangrar las narices.

es_results_raw: la tierra húmeda y fría, sus ojos cerrados como si no quisieran enfrentar la realidad de su situación, pero sus rostros reflejaban una mezcla de miedo y resignación. Algunos de ellos se movían débilmente, como si intentaran escapar de la desesperanza que los rodeaba, pero otros permanecían inmóviles, congelados en un estado de shock que parecía no tener fin. El silencio que los rodeaba era tan profundo que se podía sentir en la piel, un silencio que parecía haber sido cortado por la misma mano que los había llevado a este lugar, y que ahora parecía estar callando sus almas. El viento soplaba suavemente, pero no parecía traer consigo ningún alivio, sino más bien un recordatorio de la desolación que los rodeaba. La tierra estaba seca y muerta, y los hombres estaban congelados en ella, como si fueran parte de ella misma, como si no hubieran sido nunca más que una parte de la naturaleza, y no seres vivos con vidas que merecían ser vividas.

Bir zamanlar, bu dünyada ne kadar büyük ve güçlü olduklarını, şimdi ise ne kadar küçük ve güçsüz olduklarını hissediyorlardı. Bu düşünceler, içlerinde bir umutsuzluk ve çaresizlik hissi uyandırıyordu. Gözleri, karanlıkta birer ışığın arıyordu, ama bulamıyorlardı. Bu kadar yalnızlık ve karanlık, insanları bir araya getirmeye yetiyordu. Onlar da, birbirlerine sarıldılar ve birbirlerine sarıldıkça, bir umut ışığı ortaya çıktı.

es_results_raw: <output>—Vamos a seguir adelante, sin importar lo que pase —dijo George con una sonrisa sombría—. No podemos permitir que el miedo nos detenga. Recordemos, no somos más que dos personas en un río inmenso, pero si podemos ayudar a alguien, entonces merece la pena seguir adelante. Pero, ¿y si no podemos ayudar a nadie? ¿Y si solo estamos aquí para morir como todos los demás? La duda me atormenta, pero no puedo dejar que me detenga. Me pregunto, ¿qué es lo que realmente importa? ¿Es la vida, la muerte, la supervivencia o algo más? No lo sé, pero sé que no podemos quedarnos aquí, parados en el río, sin hacer nada. Tenemos que seguir adelante, por nosotros mismos, por nuestra curiosidad, por nuestra necesidad de descubrir lo desconocido. Y así, con una mezcla de miedo y esperanza, comenzamos a remar río arriba, hacia lo desconocido, hacia lo que solo el destino nos depara. El río nos lleva a través de un paisaje cambiante, con acantilados altos y profundos, con aguas cristalinas y oscuras, con un sol que brilla en el cielo y con una brisa que susurra secretos en nuestros oídos. El río es un mundo en sí mismo, un mundo que nos rodea, nos abraza y nos lleva a lugares desconocidos. Y nosotros, dos personas insignificantes en un río inmenso, nos sentimos pequeños, pero también nos sentimos libres, libres para explorar, libres para descubrir, libres para vivir. El río nos lleva a una aventura sin fin, a una búsqueda sin fin, a una búsqueda de respuestas que quizás nunca encontremos, pero que nos llevará a lugares que nunca imaginamos. Y así, con cada remada, con cada giro del río, nos sentimos más cerca de lo desconocido, más cerca de lo que no sabemos, más cerca de lo que no podemos imaginar. El río es un viaje sin fin, un viaje que nos llevará a lugares que nunca imaginamos, lugares que nunca sabremos si existen o no. Pero eso es lo que nos hace seguir adelante, eso es lo que nos hace seguir remando río arriba, hacia lo desconocido, hacia lo que solo el destino nos depara. Y así, con cada remada, con cada giro del río, nos sentimos más libres, más libres para explorar, más libres para descubrir, más libres para vivir. El río es un mundo en sí mismo, un mundo que nos rodea, nos abraza y nos lleva a lugares desconocidos. Y nosotros, dos personas insignificantes en un río inmenso, nos sentimos pequeños, pero también nos sentimos libres, libres para explorar, libres para descubrir, libres para vivir.
